review: I've been pleased with the device so far, as it has presented a fairly easy setup process and the introduction guide aided in maneuvering the interface.  The voice recognition is fairly well built, mostly because I have a strong accent and for me to speak clear and normal; I received a strong feedback from the built in search application.  I plan to use this device for streaming media, either from Amazon Prime, Netflix, Crackle, HuluPlus, etc..and the need for a strong WiFi signal is needed; mostly because I don't plan on using a LAN connection at all.  Therefore, it has never once dropped signal and this can be because I keep the box atop of the desk instead of inside a open cabinet.  Overall, I'm very pleased with my purchase and I will update over the course of 3-6 months of use.

review: I thought when I bought the Fire TV to replace my Roku LT that I'd be getting all or most of the TV and music apps that I currently have, maybe even some of the magazine and newspaper apps.  But, no, not by a long shot.  The number of channels that I've given up by disconnecting my Roku LT is staggering.  Yes, there are games.  But I didn't buy the Fire TV as a gaming machine.I'm willing to hang in there, waiting for Amazon to upgrade their apps so they work on the Fire TV.  I see there's a problem with Kindle Fire HD apps upgrading to the Kindle Fire HDX.  Not happy about that, but patience is a virtue, and more are becoming HDX friendly.  So some problem with apps upgrading to Fire TV is forgivable.  Not for long though.  Amazon, you need to get to work.  This is ridiculous.On the other hand, Fire TV is fast and efficient.  There's lots of storage space.  Voice search is great...just wish I could search Netflix, too.  On the whole, this is a good machine.So, hardware A-.  Software D+.Update: May 23, 2014Amazon Fire TV is winning me over completely.  The speed of the hardware and ease of Voice Search is outweighing the lack of apps.  And now that old seasons of HBO are available to Prime members, well, this is good.So, when Voice Search becomes available across all apps, the hardware score will become A+.  Because Amazon is moving quickly to add valuable apps, with PBS, ABC and Disney in the works, the software score is now B.BTW I would still like the Vudu app on Fire TV even though Flixster also has my Ultraviolet movies.  There are 5 movies which show up on Vudu which don't show up on Flixster.  All of these are Disney movies which allowed me to choose whether I wanted the digital copies on Vudu or iTunes.  I chose Vudu, thinking I'd have more flexibility.  So, I can watch these movies on my Blu-ray player, Windows 7 computer, and my Android tablet.  And yes, my old Roku.  But not on my Fire TV, Kindle HDX, Surface or Windows Phone.  Bummer!  How spoiled I became so quickly.  What is this world coming to?
